div.p: Greetings. In my last letter to you, dear brother, I wrote that the wife of our dear Gwalther, our dearest sister, was gravely ill. I now inform you that she, in the most sincere faith, at the beginning of the 14th day of this month, between 2 and 3, gave her spirit back to God and departed from here with the greatest and most admirable joy, to the greatest sorrow of us all.

Gwalther indeed bears this calamity with a very strong spirit, but he is so stunned and unlike himself that I greatly fear for him. Therefore, pray to the Lord that He does not destroy a useful instrument of the church and spares the pious.
From Geneva, our Beza writes that the state of the church in France is not in a good place. Therefore, we must pray to the Lord to thwart the bloodthirsty plans of the robbers.
In England and Scotland, there are great tumults; Satan is therefore stirring up new tragedies. May the Lord crush him! He writes more to me; however, I do not have the leisure to write more to you.
From Augsburg, it is written to me that the imperial diet has been proclaimed and will be held in Augsburg on the calends of January.

From Vienna, it is written to me from the court that there has been a long effort to restore peace between the emperor and the Turk, but with no successful outcome, the armies have been led into winter quarters.
Furthermore, there is a great scarcity and dearness of things in France, England, Lower Germany, and here too, grain is sold at a very high price; therefore, these are the last times, etc.

I will write more copiously at another time, when grief has disturbed me less. Otherwise, from Vienna, I received a most beautiful writing from a certain great man against Illyricus on the sacramental cause for us; this matter greatly consoles me, etc.
Farewell together with all our friends, whom you will greet, including the honorable councilors.
To the most excellent man, Mr. Johannes Fabricius, faithful and most vigilant pastor of the church of Chur, my esteemed and dearest lord and brother. Chur.
